that I've created specifically for this problem of finding connections between people it's called Nora it stands for
nonobvious relationship awareness I originally created it in the early 80s people were going to the
hospital spending the night and eating a meal for free because they would on the admission papers use their middle name
and change one or two digits in their social security number and it would never merge up onto their credit file and You' never collect the money so then
in the um mid 90s the the Las Vegas and other gaming locations came to me and
asked me to solve this problem they had 18 different lists of bad guys there's
something called a blackbook here for example if a one of these gaming companies transacts with these people they will lose their gaming license so
every day they're trying to evaluate off these 18 list if any of these people are transacting with them and what we created is we took all 18 lists and
every day compared everybody from all their different systems across all their different properties against all those
lists and every morning churned out um leads that would find connections between people I'm going to give you
some examples of that uh in in 2000 we started using this technology elsewhere
in Corporate America to flush out more bad guys and insiders I give you some examples of that and then post September
11th we started working with the FBI watch list in conjunction with corporative America data sets and
started finding connections between the watch list and people who had been transacting or making
reservations in the past or in the future and finding some connections that otherwise would not have been
found the just in summary the capability you're going to see is what nor does it ingests data from hundreds or thousands
of data sources we find both the obvious and the non obvious connections between
people we gener leads in the form of alert so it doesn't tell you who to shoot but it it's like a smoke detector
so it tells you where to focus investigative resources it is really a critical activity if you're going to do
transaction pattern analysis if you're doing anti-money laundering for example and you think you have five different people and each of them have five
different transactions that is a very different study than if it really is true that it's one person with 25
transactions and what Norah does it does person resolution it's figuring out when people that look different are really
the same name and my work in this field while it's been going on for some time I've
set sicked my Engineers on resolving the problem in the last three years to do this all in real time within a second or
two or three from large data sources to find these connections and if you were to fuse the data it would look something
like this now on the left side are good guys the right side are bad guys and the reason you fuse the good guys to the bad
guys is because your good guys are trusted and you're trying to find connections between good guys and bad
guys and as diagram there kind of suggests we find a zillion connections
between people but it's the red lines that are the ones that are really scary so if you can't focus into which
relationships are bad you get too many false positives and you produce useless
results a major part of the story is data quality as I mentioned earlier our largest deployment of this kind of an
architecture those boxes across the top I have a customer 4,200 daily feeds with
what might be estimated to be a half a million people in data behind all of those 4200 systems so how do you
